hints_html:
Recall the relationship between slopes of tangent lines and derivatives.

Implicitly differentiate with respect to x and then plug in \((0,1)\). Solve for \(y'\) to get the slope since the derivative at a point is equal to the slope of the tangent line to the curve at that point.

question: 2 (b)
sols_html:
Implicitly differentiating gives

\[\begin{aligned} y' + \cos y + x\tfrac{d}{dx}(\cos y) &= -\sin x \\ y' + \cos y + x(-\sin y)(y')&= -\sin x\end{aligned}\]

Plugging in \((x,y) = (0,1)\) gives

\[\begin{aligned} y' + \cos(1) + 0(-\sin(1))(y')&= -\sin (0) \\ y' + \cos(1) &= 0\\ y' &= - \cos(1)\end{aligned}\]

completing the question.
sols_raw:
Implicitly differentiating gives

<math> 
\begin{align}
y' + \cos y + x\tfrac{d}{dx}(\cos y) &= -\sin x \\
y' + \cos y + x(-\sin y)(y')&= -\sin x
\end{align}
</math>

Plugging in <math> (x,y) = (0,1)</math> gives

<math> 
\begin{align}
y' + \cos(1) + 0(-\sin(1))(y')&= -\sin (0) \\
y' + \cos(1) &= 0\\
y' &= - \cos(1)
\end{align}
</math>

completing the question.
